body: Updated example code as well. Ready for another review @miguno @ijuma @ymatsuda
@ewencp Thanks a lot for the review comments. Should be good to take another look.
@gwenshap updated and tested.

@granthenke It's a little difficult to validate the null metadata path when there's a default value because the null always gets converted to the default empty string. Did you have a way to handle this with the clientId change?

@hachikuji I had to serialize a message myself to validate the server handles nulls correctly since the protocol implementation would default to empty string. That test code is in `EdgeCaseRequestTest.testProduceRequestWithNullClientId()`

I also added `RequestResponseTest.testRequestHeaderWithNullClientId()` to test the defaulting behavior.

@hachikuji, thanks for your comments. I've incorporated all of them into e448356. Please let me know if there's anything else you think would be helpful for me to add.

One additional question I didn't catch when reviewing the Kafka PR policies: do we squash PR commits into a single one before it gets merged into `trunk`?
LGTM
@granders addressed your concern, mind giving it another pass?
@drausin Thanks for the update! I left a minor comment, but otherwise LGTM. Don't worry about squashing; our merge script does it automatically.
@ewencp if looks ok, could you please merge? Thanks.
@ewencp @gwenshap please check when you get a chance. Thanks.

@enothereska I think we should test both 0.9 and 0.10 clients when it comes to changing the message version on the fly to 0.10, but only test 0.10 clients when changing the message version on the fly to 0.9.

@ijuma On a second thought, we cannot simply keep a cached instance for the primitive typed serde, since the serializer and deserializer can be `configured`, for example, for `StringSerializer` can be configured with different encodings for key and value, etc. If we use a constant cached serde, when its serializers are configured multiple times by users.
The test, `org.apache.kafka.connect.runtime.WorkerSourceTaskTest.testCommit` failure is not related.
Either we can provide a default value of time, say always latest, or if we want to mandate users to specify it, we should put a check to make sure user provides time, if not print usage and die.
+1 on keeping the current logic.
@gwenshap ping for review.

As I discussed with @miguno offline, we will keep the default serde configs as is for now, since we may remove them in all when we have the default serdes provided for common data types like primitives as well as json / avro / kryo / etc.

I could create a new KAFKA_NETWORK_OPTS config setting and add it to the script. This could be useful in the case you want to change [proxy settings](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/net/proxies.html) for connect. Let me know whatever is preferred and I'll update the pull request.
I think KAFKA_NETWORK_OPTS would make sense, but let's wait for a committer to weigh in.

`KAFKA_NETWORK_OPTS` could be useful for connect. Then we could have people use things like `export KAFKA_NETWORK_OPTS='-Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true -Dhttp.proxyHost=1.2.3.4 -Dhttp.proxyPort=8080'` to wire up proxy settings for connectors.

@fpj I have merged with trunk and updated this patch to use the ZkClient versioned delete.

Ping @ewencp @gwenshap @Ishiihara 

Overview: this patch contains the pause/resume API which lets users suspend a connector's processing. The paused state is an instance of a connector "target state," which is stored in the config storage topic. the main reason to have it there is that it opens the door to considering the pause state when determining the task assignments for the workers (e.g. the leader can choose _not_ to assign any paused connectors). However, at the moment, pausing the connector does not cause a rebalance. Instead, each worker reads from the config topic independently. When a target state change is observed by a worker, it pauses or resumes all tasks for that connector which it owns (if there are any). Since a connector's configuration may have changed while it was paused, we always check whether a rebalance is needed after resuming.

At the moment, there are only two implemented target states: "started" and "paused." When a connector is first configured, it is in the "started" state regardless whether any target states have been written to the config topic. As state changes occur, the new state is written to the topic. When a connector is deleted, we write null for the value to ensure cleanup.

Pause Behavior: the meaning of "pause" depends on the type of task:
- Connector: pause means calling stop() on the connector.
- Source task: pause means we stop calling task.poll() for new data. 
- Sink task: all assigned partitions are paused using KafkaConsumer.pause(). Significantly, the worker stays part of the consumer group.

Additional notes: I did some minor refactors here and there, but the most significant one was extracting an interface from KafkaConfigStorage and updating StandaloneHerder to use an in-memory implementation of it. This was a bit awkward since KafkaConfigStorage was designed around a snapshot which is recomputed on config updates, but hopefully it will allow us to move more common functionality into AbstractHerder down the road.

Known Gaps: the main gap that comes to mind is additional unit/integration tests for the Herder implementations. Probably documentation also. It would be nice if you could point out places where additional docs/comments are needed.
LGTM

@Ishiihara Really close to LGTM now. The only final things I noticed when testing this:
- The default value in `"definition"` seems to come as `""` even for configs without a default value (maybe only for strings?).
- ConnectorConfig probably needs to be updated to use the new ConfigDef parameters (e.g., it does not have a nice `display_name` right now.

Otherwise, it all looks good!

@ewencp For configs without default value, the default value field will be filled in with `NO_DEFAULT_VALUE`, which is an empty string. That explains why the default value in `"definition"` is `""`.  Also added the additional fields for configs defined in `ConnectorConfig`.
General comment: I think the Serdes part needs some better unit test coverage.  There was at least one bug that I ran into that should have been caught by tests, not by code review IMHO.

@guozhangwang Updated.  `./gradlew checkstyleMain checkstyleTest` looks good now for streams.  I also removed some unused logger fields and fixed a docstring.  Initially, I didn't want to touch any other code lines (like unused imports) because these are unrelated to this PR, but hey, I'm flexible. ;-)
Looks like I don't have the power to merge, so I'll leave it to you or the powers that be to handle that :)

Adding a few more unit tests.

@becketqin : In general, there is no strong guarantee that the callbacks will be called in send order since messages can go to different partitions and the processing of each partition is independent. Messages that go to the same partition will be processed in order. Perhaps it's useful to preserve the ordering in that case (e.g. ordering per key), but maybe less critical. Do you think this is a blocker for 0.10.0?

I think it should be user responsibility to make sure that they are not changing partition count to what it is already. Any reason why you can not perform that check before trying to bump up partitions count?

@SinghAsDev as the user opening the JIRA stated, they use the scripts as part of automaticon. Having the script behave idempotently is actually simpler than checking the number of partitions and bumping up only if needed.
@miguno Ready for review again.
LGTM, merged to trunk.
LGTM, merged to trunk.

I would have liked this to go into 0.10.0 but I'm not sure it is feasible given that the latest patch needs a review and deprecates a number of configurations. I haven't done this in the current patch but if everyone agrees with the general approach then I would also emit a formal warning about the deprecated configurations if specified in the broker configuration or topic-level configuration (via the `TopicCommand` utilities).
@jjkoshy I agree that it's a bit tricky to get this in given the number of deprecations. I think it probably needs to be discussed in the mailing list. Would a KIP be appropriate?

Validated and LGTM.

@junrao It seems the PR name is misleading... Actually what I meant was that the callbacks can be fired out of order even for messages sent to the same partitions. This is important because it cause trouble for people who are depending on the callback firing order for strict order messaging. 

It would be great if we can fix this in 0.10.0. But if the fix requires some bigger change, maybe we can leave this out of 0.10.0 given the issue has been there for a while. Personally I feel that throwing exception to user instead of firing callback in `send()` is a reasonable band-aid solution. It is not ideal that the users might receive ApiException when they call `send()`, but this seems less a problem than firing callback out of order. Maybe we can do this now, and later on we can make things right after fixing the exception hierarchy. That said, I am also fine if we decide to fix it post 0.10.0 and do it in the ideal way in one shot.
@hachikuji Can you rebase against trunk? KAFKA-3315 just get merged which also modifies `AbstractHerder` and other related classes.

This seems fine to me. I focused on the shared part of the code as I'm not too familiar with the streams code. Given that we are not really taking advantage of `configure` for the built-in `Serdes`, I still think we should make better use of constants instead of returning a new instance every time (both on `Serdes` and individual `Serde` instances like `DoubleSerde`). However, that is an implementation change that could be done in a separate JIRA and doesn't need to block this.
Sorry, but when would a topic have 0 partitions?
@granthenke, nice catch. Can you please add a test in `RequestResponseTest`? It should be straightforward.

Did you reproduce the original issue? because the code you fixed doesn't seem to be the same one where the bug occurred...

If you did, can you post sample output?
